description: From Middle English hopen, from Old English hopian (“hope”), from Proto-West Germanic *hopōn, further etymology unclear.

verbs.description: hope (third-person singular simple present hopes, present participle hoping, simple past and past participle hoped)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive) To want something to happen, with a sense of expectation that it might.
examples: I hope everyone enjoyed the meal.
I am still hoping that all will turn out well.

entries.meaning: To be optimistic; be full of hope; have hopes.
(intransitive) To place confidence; to trust with confident expectation of good; usually followed by in.

examples: I hope you all the best.

description: From Middle English hope, from Old English hopa (“hope, expectation”), from the same source as the verb hope.

entries.meaning: (countable or uncountable) The feeling of trust, confidence, belief or expectation that something wished for can or will happen.
examples: I still have some hope that I can get to work on time.
After losing my job, there's no hope of being able to afford my world cruise.
There is still hope that we can find our missing cat.

entries.meaning: (countable) A person or thing that is a source of hope.
examples: We still have one hope left: my roommate might see the note I left on the table.

entries.meaning: (Christianity, uncountable) The virtuous desire for future good.

description: From Middle English hope (“a valley”), from Old English hōp (found only in placenames). More at hoop.

entries.meaning: (Northern England, Scotland) A hollow; a valley, especially the upper end of a narrow mountain valley when it is nearly encircled by smooth, green slopes; a combe.

description: From Icelandic hóp (“a small bay or inlet”). Cognate with English hoop.

entries.meaning: A sloping plain between mountain ridges.
(Scotland) A small bay; an inlet; a haven.
